title: What's News: Business & Finance — WSJ
text:
This article is being republished as part of our daily reproduction of WSJ.com articles that also appeared in the U.S. print edition of The Wall Street Journal (September 12, 2019).

Purdue Pharma has secured support from 23 states and thousands of local governments for a multibillion-dollar deal that could enable the company to resolve much of the opioid litigation it faces.

Hong Kong's stock exchange made an unsolicited $36.6 billion bid to acquire the LSE, a deal that would unite two of the world's major trading hubs.

California passed employment legislation that challenges the business model of gig-economy firms such as Uber and Lyft.

Oracle said Mark Hurd, one of the company's two chief executives, will take a medical leave of absence.

Trump renewed his pressure on the Fed, calling for the central bank to cut rates to zero or less.

Forever 21 is planning to file for bankruptcy, adding to the rising toll on many bricks-and-mortar chains.

The Dow notched its sixth straight session of gains, rising 0.8% amid a rally among tech shares.

Groupon is pursuing an acquisition amid discontent among shareholders about the firm's financial performance and stock price.

KPMG's former No. 2 auditor was sentenced to prison for his role in the "steal the exam" scandal.

Boeing said the return to service of the 737 MAX could vary across countries unless regulators can agree on a single path to approvals.

(END) Dow Jones Newswires

September 12, 2019 02:47 ET (06:47 GMT)
